data.title: "Cannot read property 'substring' of undefined" using elm + elm-format
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install/configure plugins: elm, elm-format
2. attempt to format Elm code.

Result is `Error Cannot read property 'substring' of undefined`

This is not reproducible in VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider.

data.title: VSCode opens the same file in multiple editors if the names use different cases
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a file named LICENSE.txt
2. Run "Code --reuse-window LICENSE.txt"
3. Run "Code --reuse-window license.txt"
4. Observe that VSCode opens 2 editor windows.
5. Expect: VSCode detects the two file names are actually the same file, and only opens one file instead.

    ![case](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12519738/21579035/51e6ca88-cf4e-11e6-8ac4-32a911f2420d.JPG)

This is especially annoying when dealing with MSVC project, when click the build error message and a new window is opened.
1. Create a C++ project. The file name contains mixed upper and lower case. Open the file d:\git\Test\Main.cpp in editor
2. Create a task.json and use msbuild to build the project
3. Build. Assume there is an syntax error like the following. Notice that cl.exe converts filename to lower case
  d:\git\test\main.cpp(10): error C2144: syntax error: 'int' should be preceded by ';' [d:\git\Test\Test.vcxproj]
4. Click the status "Problem" icon. Select the error message from the panel. The main.cpp is opened in editor, right next to Main.cpp

data.title: TextMate grammar regexes able to only match a single line
data.body:
![Image of improper multiline syntax highlighting](http://i.imgur.com/PIV2uAM.png)

Everything between the parentheses should be coloured green, but the matching stops after the first line ends.

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10 64-bit (4.8.0-30-generic)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone [this minimal repro sample](https://github.com/tambry/vscode_multiline_match_bug).
2. Open the folder of the sample in VS Code.
3. Press F5 to run the extension in a new VS Code instance.
4. In the new instance open the *test.matchbug* file that's in the repro sample's root directory.
5. Code is improperly highlighted.

[How the regex should match](https://regex101.com/r/W29FWu/1)

- Text scaling factor: 1.00

I've tried various combinations of antialiasing and hinting settings but they all look as bad or worse.

data.title: Debugging babel transpiled code not fully working with node2
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Fedora 25

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use babel-register to transpile source files.
2. Set breakpoints in the original source files.
3. Try to hover variables if breakpoint gets hit.

The problem is, that the breakpoints gets hit but the values of variables doesn't get shown if you hover them. If you add the variable as a watch expression the value of it gets shown in the list. This only happens if you use the **node2** debugger. With the "old" **node** debugger everything works as expected.

This is my setup of babel-register:

```
require('babel-register')({
    plugins: ['transform-async-to-generator'],
    sourceMaps: true,
    retainLines: true
});

require('./src/app');
```

This is my launch.json: 
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [{
        "name": "Launch Program",
        "type": "node2",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/index.js",
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "sourceMaps": true
    }, {
        "name": "Attach to Process",
        "type": "node2",
        "request": "attach",
        "port": 9229
    }]
}
```

data.title: Show selected line count in the editor status bar
data.body:
This pull request adds selected lines count in case of non-collapsed selection.

![This is how it does looks like](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5353898/21575506/1d462566-cf0e-11e6-9c72-e3fb93614a5b.png)

It fixes #932 and #15344 (which is a dup of former one).

## Remarks

### Multiple selections

I did not add lines selected information in case of multiple selection on purpose. Reason for this is that you might have a selection like that (bracket marks range):

```
a[aaaa
b]b[b]b[b
c]cccc
```

In that case we effectively have 3 lines selected, however with the simplified implementation that just adds TextModel.getLineCountInRange() for each range, it would give us 5 lines (2 + 1 + 2).

So instead of showing possibly buggy value, I decided not to show it at all.

If you'll like the feature, I can implement more clever way to count unique lines for multiple selection, just let me know.

### nlsSingleSelectionRange default string adjusted

You will note that I've also added "characters" part in case of single selection range.

```const nlsSingleSelectionRange = nls.localize('singleSelectionRange', "Ln {0}, Col {1} ({3} lines, {2} characters selected)");```

### `monaco.d.ts`

While adding method ITextModel it looks like it got automatically added to `monaco.d.ts`, because I don't recall adding it there. Just worth to mention, as I'm not super familiar with Code internals.

data.title: vscode doesn't replace problems in problems view after they are fixed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Mac OS El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a custom problem matcher
2. Run problem matcher, it produces some errors
3. Fix those errors
4. Run problem matcher again
5. The old errors are still there, they only reset on full quit/reinstall.

data.title: FIrst call to vscode.startDebug does not show debug starting indicator (blue line)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.12.1 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an extension
2. Add a command that calls 'vscode.startDebug'
3. Call the command while debugging extension
Expected: VS Code shows visual indicator (moving blue line) while debug session starts up
Actual: VS Code starts debug session but never shows indicator
4. Stop debug session and restart by calling command a second time
Visual indicator shows up while debug session is starting.

data.title: Can no longer expand Array types in Debug console when debugging extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

When developing a vscode extension or any other type of JavaScript file, when debugging, execute commands like

```
console.log(['hello', 'world']);
```

The debug console will show:

```
Array [2]
```

But there is no arrow next to it that allows you to expand and view the contents. I'm pretty sure in a previous version you could examine arrays in this manner. Am I incorrect about this?

data.title: vscode + python virtual environment + mac terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

When launching vscode from terminal with command `code` while a virtual python environment is activated (e.g. `workon myenv`) it would be nice if vscode uses the same virtualenv in it's integrated terminal.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open terminal
2. activate a virtual python environment (e.g. `workon DJANGO` -->  magic from virtualenvwrapper)
3. call `code`
4. in vscode open integrated terminal
5. with `pip list` check in which python environment you are

NOW: vscode is in default python env
BETTER: use virtualenv from which vscode was started

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

1. Help > Release Notes

Blue hyperlink text is hard to read and appears to be smaller than rest of text. You can see this by looking at the 1.8.1 Recovery Build "key issues" link.

This is especially problematic for the in-product release notes since Zoom In crops the display and neither editor.fontSize nor markdown.preview.fontSize applies.

data.title: Better line wrapping for markdown files (and other relevant file types)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Not sure if this is possible, but it'd make the markdown editing experience better. Line wrapping currently only considers indentation. Is there any way to adjust the wrapping indent level based on additional contextual information? It'd mean that rather than wrapping like this (current behaviour):

```md
- Item 1
  - Item 2
  - lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit
  amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet
  - Item 3
- Item 4
```

... it could instead wrap like this:

```md
- Item 1
  - Item 2
  - lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit
    amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet lorem ipsum dolor sit amet
  - Item 3
- Item 4
```

data.title: Debugger does not stop on function breakpoint
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.2 (16C67)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a simple Javascript file with a function that you want to break on
2. In the debugger, add the functions name to the breakpoint list
3. Run debugger 

![function breakpoint doesn t break](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2437424/21572717/0b3d59dc-cea2-11e6-8c48-9f68f7dee518.gif)

I was following [the documentation on using the debugger](http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/debugging#_function-breakpoints). As far as I can tell there wasn't a detail I missed.

Here's my `launch.json` if it helps.

    {
        "version": "0.2.0",
        "configurations": [
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "launch",
                "name": "Launch Program",
                "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.js",
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
                "stopOnEntry": true
            },
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "attach",
                "name": "Attach to Process",
                "port": 5858
            }
        ]
    }

I used the node configuration. The only thing I added was the `stopOnEntry` option. 

Please let me know if I can provide any other information.

data.title: VS Code refuses to install any extensions, Green Install button says, "Installing" then never changes, even after 20 minutes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro
- .Net Framework version 4.6 Installed
- Visual Studio 2010 Installed
- At home, no proxy settings.  
- Firewall is off
- Uninstalled, re-installed at least 10x
- Installed version 1.7 same problem
- Installed VSCode in different folder
- Tried rebooting
- Tried changing "http.proxyStrictSSL": false and "http.proxyStrictSSL": true
- Tried installing VS 2015 Community, Uninstalled
- Tried installing .Net Core, Uninstalled
- Tried turning on all privacy settings to ON and to OFF, 
- Tried a different computer on the same network, a laptop, worked fine, can install extensions.

None of these have worked

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Windows 10, install, click Extensions, Install, never installs, just says Installing 
 

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24845514/21570777/d3c39862-ce8e-11e6-96f7-3e3092bdbbe2.png)

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24845514/21570828/453123f2-ce8f-11e6-9169-9b767d21e919.png)

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24845514/21570865/9fdcfae2-ce8f-11e6-8829-d4ad39d34755.png)
